columns.text: In this problem, we will basically solve for the degree of operating leverage (DOL) of the same project in Exercise 27 and verify whether it holds true for any change in the quantity.

As we can recall, these are the base values that we will use in this computation:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Fixed Cost}&=\$1,025,000\\
\text{Time}&=0.22\\
\text{Depreciation}&=\$860,000\\
\text{Operating Cashflow}&=\$1,729,700
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting these into the equation, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{DOL}&=1+\dfrac{\$1,025,000 \times (1-0.22)-(0.22 \times \$860,000)}{\$1,729,700}\\[15 pt]
&=1.3528
\end{aligned}$$

This means that for every $1\%$ increase in the quantity, the OCF increases by $1.3528\%$

For the sensitivity computation in Exercise 28, we can assume that there is a $1,000$ ton increase in the quantity sold. This will give us:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=[(\text{Price}-\text{variable cost})\times \text{Quantity} - \text{Fixed Cost}]\\
& \times (1-\text{Time}) +(\text{Time} \times \text{Depreciation})\\[15 pt]
&=[(\$290-\$190) \times 31,000 - \$1,025,000]\\
&\times (1-0.22)+(0.22 \times \$860,000)\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,807,700
\end{aligned}$$

Using this formula for DOL, we will see if the values are the same:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{DOL}&=\dfrac{\Delta \text{Operating Cashflow}}{\Delta \text{Quantity}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{(\$1,807,700-\$1,729,000)\div\$1,729,000}{(31,000-30,000) \div{30,000}}\\[15 pt]
&=1.3655
\end{aligned}$$

This means that for every $1$ unit increase in the quantity, the OCF increases by $\$1.3655$

Both answers are acceptable since the solution in Step 3 presents the answer in terms of percent increase in each category while the solution in Step 5 shows the increase in OCF in terms of dollars with respect to the change in quantity in terms of number of units.
